Ruth Eton.Action: Performs a heartfelt, emotional song with sincerity, engaging the audience and showing vulnerability.
Performs a complex jazz vocal piece confidently and skillfully, maintaining tempo and engaging the audience.
Leads her accompanist Eddie Farrell, whose performance is notably less skilled, displaying her own superior musical ability.
Greets her agents warmly, inviting them to sit and make themselves at home despite being busy changing clothes.
Responds with humor and lightheartedness to the news about Eddie being dropped from the show.
Shows no sign of anger or resentment about bad news impacting her partner, maintaining a calm and friendly demeanor.
Delivers a complex, rhythmically challenging musical refrain confidently and receives multiple curtain calls.
Maintains poise and humor when confronted with difficult news about her partner being ousted.
Engages openly and cleverly with her agents, showing awareness and readiness to hear bad news.
Does not immediately react negatively to the news about Eddie; instead approaches it rationally and inquisitively.
Advocates passionately and strategically for Eddie, proposing a plan to develop his skills and stall for time with the agents.
Shows emotional vulnerability (voice breaking) and willingness to compromise her own interests to support Eddie.
Attempts to manipulate the situation by suggesting to lie about her health to stall the agents.
Offers Eddie encouraging and specific advice on singing with patience and warmth.
Expresses commitment and appreciation to Eddie, saying she wouldn't go on without him and is happy to have him by her side.
Critiques Eddie's singing technique constructively and offers a demonstration to improve it.
Expresses emotional support and confidence in Eddie's progress in a caring manner.
Looks on proudly as Eddie performs and supports him.
Shakes head and walks away when young women push past her to get to Eddie.
Is dismissed by others as unnecessary in the act and told she can 'play the small time' while Eddie advances.
Stares thoughtfully at Eddie's photo, showing emotional vulnerability but also a moment of reflection.
Attempts to maintain composure when greeted by Marge despite evident sadness.
Declines to eat despite food being offered, possibly indicating emotional distraction or lack of practical self-care.
Admits emotional vulnerability and sorrow over Eddie's changed behavior, showing sincere feelings.
Seeks emotional support from Marge, showing trust and openness.
Expresses feelings of gratitude despite personal hurt, indicating good-natured loyalty.
Omission: Does not respond with bitterness or harshness toward Eddie despite feeling let down.
Expresses difficulty in working without Eddie, shows emotional vulnerability but self-awareness.
Admits to being distracted and unable to move on yet, despite efforts.
Considers trying to forget Eddie and seeks help to do so, showing willingness to address her problem.
Moves closer to the table, accepts food from Marge, laughs warmly, shows openness in conversation.
Moves closer to the table, puts a napkin in her lap, sips tea thoughtfully, and engages in light conversation showing social ease and reflective thought.
Is mentioned indirectly in a newspaper comment indicating she taught Eddie Farrell everything he knew, implying skill and capability.
Performs a difficult and emotional torch song in one long glorious take with evident emotional control and skill.
Walks off stage head bowed and listless, showing emotional drain and perhaps diminished confidence.
Greets Eddie warmly despite past difficulties; takes his hand and invites him to audition; grins and rests her head on his shoulder, showing affection.
Pauses thoughtfully and assesses Eddie's return before engaging with him confidently, inviting him for an audition the next day.
Avoids eye contact initially with Eddie, indicating emotional uncertainty or discomfort.
Defends Eddie Farrell passionately despite rejection, offering to support and coach him personally, prioritizing his development over money.
Shows upset and emotional vulnerability when faced with the agents' disapproval and Eddie's rejection.
Appeals sincerely to Saul as a friend and tries to negotiate a delay to help Eddie improve.
Looks sadly at photo of Eddie, buries her head in her shoulder.
Greets roommate Marge politely despite her own sadness.
Laughs with Marge, showing friendly engagement.
Tells Marge to fix something for herself despite Ruth not feeling hungry, indicating consideration.
Stepped in as an unexpected guest performer at a benefit show when all other stars failed to appear, demonstrating reliability and readiness.
Sings a heartfelt, sorrowful torch song revealing vulnerability and emotional depth.
Responds briefly and listlessly to a friendly greeting backstage, showing emotional exhaustion but not hostility.
